title: Did you know it costs almost half a million IP to buy all the champions?
body:
In a few champion releases, probably by this time next year, it WILL cost half a million IP to buy all of the champions. 
A lot of players, particularly older ones who were here when Riot gave out more IP, don't think the champion reduction schedule needs updated, and they'll frequently  point to the first win of the day giving out a lot of extra IP.

Let's be generous and say a first win of the day+normal game win is 250 IP. If you just started playing League of Legends today, it will take you 1,916 days (or 5.2 years) if all you do is play  one winning game a a day. And that is to get to the amount of champions we have right now. That's not even including Tahm Kench. 

Let's say the new player plays 4 games a day with a 50% win rate for 550 IP total. It would take them 870 days, or 2.3  years, to get to where we are now. That's almost 1800** hours sunk into the game at an exorbitant rate to be 2 years behind. 

New players are starting extremely behind. This game is not new anymore. Riot can still turn a hefty profit while allowing new players to succeed. They needs to SIGNIFICANTLY rework the IP reduction schedule, revamp champion prices entirely, or come up with another plan to make this game accessible to new and newer players. 

>6300 IP champions x 32 = 201,600 IP
4800 IP champions x 35 = 168,000 IP
3150 IP champions x 25 = 78,750 IP
1350 IP champions x 21 = 28,350 IP
450 IP champions x 12 = 5,400 IP

>Total Amount for  all champions: 482,100
Minus 3 Free Promotional Champions:  478,950

And by the way, that doesn't include runes and rune pages.

Edit: **Corrected math. 2 hours for 4 games x 870 is not even close to 2500. If the games take 40 minutes each, then it's close to 2500.

replies.body:
I have every single champion, all bought with IP, but to be honest I never play more than half of them.

I don't think not being able to easily have all the champions is that crippling to new players, but the cost of runes ***is***.

You can play the game fairly happily with maybe 20 champions, but you need at least five full rune pages to be able to compete fairly.

Honestly, I think it has more to do with disincentive to play than being competitive. Why would you want to play if you only enjoy playing 2-3 champs of the 20 cheap ones  you own, but the new ones you liked during free week will take months to get?

 I also do disagree on the runes, you really do only need basic ad/ap pages to play competitively. Everything else is just sprinkles.

I didn't mean that you can play happily with only the 20 cheapest champions, but rather that you don't need the full roster.

For example, I looked at some of the champions that I play regularly or have played regularly in previous seasons, and picked 16 of those, which gives me 3-5 champions that I enjoy playing in every role.  Admittedly, my selection mostly included mid-priced (3150 and 4800) champions, with only one 450 and three 6300s, but the total cost of that champion pool is 60,000 IP.  A lot, but only a small slice of the half-a-million to buy all champions.

As for runes, I'd consider you to need at least these pages: AP mid / mage, AD champion, attack speed / jungler, support.  That's two additional runepages that you need to buy for 12600.

For essential runes, I'd say you need at least: AD marks, AD quints, flat health seals, scaling MR glyphs, flat AP glyphs, flat AP quints, attack speed marks, attack speed quints, gold-per-10 seals, gold-per-10 quints.
That shopping list is 32910 IP.
(You could get that cheaper by not taking the gold-per-10 and swapping out the flat health for the cheaper flat armour seals.)

The total for my "minimum runes" setup is 45,510 IP, almost as much as my example "decent champion roster".

I'd say most players will want more runes and rune pages than that, most likely at least one page dedicated to their main champion, and at least a few of the other rune types, including hybrid damage, mana regen, CDR, and flat MR.

Having more champions to play is nice.  It lets you try other things, or to swap in draft queues.  Yes, I can understand why this costs so much - it's to encourage players to spend real money to unlock the champions faster, and also to give players a sense of accomplishment when they get to unlock more champions through IP.

However, having to sink such a huge amount of IP into just having the necessary runes to play effectively is harsh on new players.  They have to choose between the fun choice of unlocking a new champion, or the necessary choice of buying runes and runepages so that they can play their champions effectively.
Needing to buy runes also effectively makes the champions feel even more expensive, since players have less IP to spend on them when they need to buy runes.

My perspective on League has always been, "you get what you pay for"

Take a traditional mmo for example. Back when WoW was released it was $60 plus $15 a month in subscription fees. Now think about applying that to League, $60 worth of RP when you start playing and then $15 of RP a month. I'm not going to take the time to do the math but That seems like a healthy amount of champions and would leave you to save up your IP for runes.
where did you find this information?

You go to the store in the client. Uncheck "Not Owned". Check sort by IP. You count the champions in each price tier. You multiply the number of champions by their prices. Then you add them all together.
Math ftw
Oh and lets not forget this is neglecting the minimal 5-7 rune pages and runes you need.

I said that statement with the context in mind. I own all the 450s and 1350s.

You're also not a newbie, considering you've been playing for over a year.

During that year, every champ (with a few exceptions) should have been available in the free week rotation between 2 to 4 times.  Granted, real life gets in the way.  You can't always play when a certain champ is free to play.  And even if you can, sometimes you just want to play what you want to play, rather than be forced into trying out a free champ simply because you might not get the same chance again for 3 or more months.

An on-demand, try before you buy feature with some low cost (or no cost but really limited opportunity like Heroes of the Storm) would be better than trying to simply reduce IP costs across the board.  Because no matter how much you lower the price, people are still going to complain that it could be even lower.  And at some point, the cost is going to be so low that there's no perceived value in unlocking the champ.  And when that happens, the sense of accomplishment and progress for unlocking champs also diminishes.
I would personally like it if there were champion IP sales, maybe even if they are 25% off their IP cost? Would help a bit with the prices.
